entry.title: Mechanim Animation From Transform
entry.content:
The below example demonstrates how to implement mechanim animations on objects based on their transform (movement) each frame.

This means that this can be applied to both player controlled objects na lso objects being manipulated via code/automatically.

Example

An example of this can be seen in the following video (video is from a time travel prototype game that I am developing).



Code

(Scroll down to see small explanation after code)

Each update the Velocity (Vector3) of the object is taken (this is the difference between this frames transform and the previous frames transform).

This value is then passed to the animator (if one exists) which sets the specified movement float (“Forward“ in my example)

Reusing this code

If using this code on your own projects you should assume 1 for the variables T.TimeScaleAbs and T.TimeScale.
entry.summary: The below example demonstrates how to implement mechanim animations on objects based on their transform (movement) each frame.

entry.title: Time Game 1 - Implementing Time Travel
entry.content:
What is it

This is my initial implementation of the time travel mechanic written with Unity3D.

  • Red box is the current player.
  • Level goes back to beginning when entering the Time Machine
  • White boxes are the previous versions of yourself

How Does it Work - “The Code”

Note

I’m not sure how others have done this before, but this is how I did it.
(as of time of writing)

The process can be split into 2 parts.

  1. Recording
  2. Playback

1. Recording

This is actually pretty simple. A loop was created a loop that calls the method TakeSnapshot() at a specific SampleRate.

Reusing this code

  • If using this code on your own projects you should assume 1 for the variable T.TimeScaleAbs.
    I will try to explain what T is in future posts for this prototype.
  • RecordedData is a type I’m using to save the data into.

The TakeSnapshot() method records any information that we want to know about the object. Currently only the Position and Rotation are recorded.

Note

In future other pieces of information may need to be recorded.
(for example the Scale could be of interest while recording).

2. Playback

The playback works much the same as the record code.
It starts at the beginning of the recorded data and cycles through each data item at the same rate it was recorded calling the NextSnapshot() method each time.

The NextSnapshot() method loads the next position and rotation value and saves it into a variable _desiredMoveLocation

Each update the object is then moved (position and rotation) towards the _desiredMoveLocation.

Lerping

The position and rotation of the object is calculated each update using the Lerp function.
(this creates a smooth movement instad of a jerky movement).

Why

I have always been interested in time travel. Films, novels, games. The idea of time travel has always intrigued me.

What next

I will post updates of my progress as I add more to this game prototype.

My immediate list of todo’s

  • Characters (that move) instead of boxes
  • Add Level Exit/Completion point
  • Save playthroughs to file
  • Replay system

Have a question?

Feel free to ask me anything (I have overlooked some internal workings in this post).
I also have a Unity3d Forum WIP post for this:
https://forum.unity3d.com/threads/wip-time-game-time-travel.435684/

entry.title: My Boxstarter Script
entry.content:
Whats the problem

Setting up a new machine is always a bit of a pain. Wouldn’t it be nice if your machine could just get the software you wanted and install it for you.

Welcome BoxStarter

BoxStarter.org can install all of your software out with a single command.

My Script

My current Home Development Script can be found at my GitHub Repository.

Here it is at the time of writing this post:


Boxstarter is able to use Chocolatey Packages which means it has access to many many pieces of software.

Other Windows 10 Options

Alternatively you can now use a Package Manager in Windows.

Windows 10 now includes a Package Manager. Check out my personal favourite Chocolatey which includes many many Packages

entry.title: 3D Printer 4 - Auto Bed Levelling
entry.content:
Video of the G29 (Auto level) command.



This process involves using 3 Force Sense Resistors (FSR’s) in order to use the actual print head as the z-probe.

Code can be found in Johan’s Github Branch:

github.com/jcrocholl/Marlin/tree/fsr

Here are some images of how the sensors are attached to the printer (under the bed):

entry.title: Conky Config
entry.content:
I have had a couple of queries regarding my conky config that can be seen on my new arch desktop screenshot:

In order to recreate this config you will need the following:

https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/conky-colors/
https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/conky-nvidia/
https://www.archlinux.org/packages/?name=lm_sensors

Here is the conky config file (feel free to copy as needed):
https://gist.github.com/Gaweph/63d48a9c43e1b256ca8c8a9a7717fed7



wlp4s0 and enp3s0f0 are the network device IDS, so you will need to substitute your own.

If you would like to modify the icons then theres lots of them in the ttf:
https://github.com/helmuthdu/conky_colo … onkycolors

PLEASE NOTE:

I’m sure there’s a better way of getting the CPU temps. Please let me know if this is the case.
I’m not sure that the Ethernet if else statements are working correctly.

FURTHER READING:

Here’s some lovelly looking conky-colors stuff:
http://helmuthdu.deviantart.com/art/CONKY-COLORS-244793180
And the conky Git pagee if you want to see the source and who made it:
https://github.com/helmuthdu/conky_colors
entry.summary: I have had a couple of queries regarding my conky config that can be seen on my new arch desktop screenshot:

entry.title: 3D Printer 3 - Calibration
entry.content:
Here is a video of my printer doing a calibration.



Calibrating the print head height is proving to be quite difficult. A good article on this can be found here:

Minow - Calibrating a Delta 3D Printer

Delta Printers Only

This calibration process is for a delta style printers only (like my 3DR)

As you can see the prints are getting significantly better.

Its not quite there, but I would say its close.
entry.summary: Here is a video of my printer doing a calibration.

entry.title: A week with Arch
entry.content:
After a week using Arch, getting the desktop just the way I want it, and generally getting to grips with what it means to have to read up on everything you install and configure; I must say I like Arch.

Here is what I finally have (I went for XFCE because it is lightweight).

What I like

I’m very happy with the speed and ease of use so far.

Arch makes no assumptions, this means you literally have to configure everything. An example of this is that I could not get thunar to auto mount and add a desktop icon for my USB drives. After some research (amazing Arch documentation) this was simply a case of enabling the thunar volume manager alongside lxpolkit.

Bottom Line

Things may take a little longer to get working and configured. but this results in no cruft at all in your system, and you leave knowing how things work in much more depth and are then able to problem solve in future. And when something does’t work you really get to go into the documentation (of which there is ample amounts of information on everything).

I would say that I have learnt more on how a linux distribution works in my first week with arch, than I have in around 3 years of Ubuntu and Mint.

There is something very satisfying about knowing exactly what is running on your system.
entry.summary: After a week using Arch, getting the desktop just the way I want it, and generally getting to grips with what it means to have to read up

entry.title: Arch Linux New Install
entry.content:
Something New

I have been contemplating re-installing my main OS. Currently I’m running Mint ( 14 - Cinnamon) and Windows 7. I have always wanted to install Gentoo, but I just can’t bring myself to doing it, everything I read suggests it will take hours upon hours to install. Then there’s the maintenance, apparently everything is compiled at install time, which can increase installation times.

Arch

I have been looking at Arch Linux, and I think this provides a good middle ground. You get to build a system running only what you configure and install, but it seems easier and less daunting that a full Gentoo install.

One thing I would like to highlight is that the DOCUMENTATION IS AMAZING!, really really helpful, if you need to know it, it’s in there. Check out the Beginners Guide if you need help getting going.

After 2 hours of work, here is what I have:

(It still needs a lot of work, this is simply the stock xfce, with chromium installed)

Something to note is that my previous install of Mint had encrypted my home folders with ecryptfs (standard ubuntu encryption). This was easily used with my new install by following the Auto-Mount steps in this guide.
entry.summary:
Something New

I have been contemplating

entry.title: 3D Printer 2 - Leaking
entry.content:
Too Hot

While trying to calibrate my hot end I set my extruder speed too high which meant that the plastic was being pushed into the hot end faster than it could be extruded.

Back in business

After taking it apart I found that it was due to the inner PLA of the JHead slipping a bit inside. I have now reconstructed the hot end and its clean and tight.
entry.summary:
Too Hot

While trying to calibrate my hot end I set my extr

entry.title: 3D Printer 1 - Build
entry.content:
Background

I was inspired to create this printer after seeing a very informative video by Richard Horne on his 3DR RepRap Delta Printer (his tutorial series on the printer is very helpful and covers all aspects of the build process).
The printer is a Delta printer (a design made famous by jcrocholl and his Rostock printer.
